sub_topic: Using integration to find the volume of a solid
message_1: A cylindrical tank has a height of 10 meters and a radius of 5 meters. Find the volume of water in the tank if it is half-full using integration to calculate the volume.
message_2:
To find the volume of water in the tank when it is half-full, we can use the method of integration. We will integrate the area of the circular cross-sections of the tank along the height of the tank, from 0 to half of the height (5 meters).

The equation for the area of a circle is A = πr^2, where r is the radius. Since the radius of the tank is constant (5 meters), the area of each circular cross-section is A = π(5^2) = 25π square meters.

Now, we will integrate the area along the height of the tank from 0 to 5 meters:

Volume = ∫[A(h) dh] from 0 to 5
Volume = ∫[25π dh] from 0 to 5

Now, we will integrate:

Volume = [25πh] from 0 to 5

Now, we will evaluate the integral at the limits:

Volume = (25π(5)) - (25π(0))
Volume = 125π - 0
Volume = 125π cubic meters

So, the volume of water in the tank when it is half-full is 125π cubic meters.
